ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS



    Mr Speaker: I have had a message that the Prime Minister may be a few minutes late.

    On the matter of Questions, there is a Standing Order which provides for a contingency of that nature. It is Standing Order 20 (3):

    `If a Minister [I am reading the relevant portion] who is to answer a question, is absent, the question shall, if he then be present, be taken after all other questions appearing on the Order Paper have been disposed of.'

If by then the Prime Minister is not present, there are other provisions in the Standing Order which will apply.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): On a point of order, Mr Speaker, Sir,I have been asked by the Prime Minister to reply to Question No. 4.

    Mr Speaker: I will then call Question No. 4. Mr Tan Cheng Tong.
LONDON TALKS (1963) (Expenditure from Government funds on Government officers and Prime Minister's wife)


    4. Mr Tan Cheng Tong asked the Prime Minister what is the total expenditure from Government funds on the Government officers who attended the recent London talks; and whether the expenses or any part thereof of his wife during her stay in London were met out of such funds.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee (for the Prime Minister): The expenditure incurred on bills so far received for air passages and other expenditure amounts to $44,808.

    Mrs Lee Kuan Yew's travelling and other expenditure was on the Prime Minister's personal account. It is not borne by the Government.

Column: 256

HAWKERS
(Number arrested and amount of fines collected from 3rd June, 1959, to 31st July, 1961, and from 1st August, 1961, to 30th June, 1963)


    6. Mr Tan Cheng Tong asked the Minister for Health and Law how many hawkers were arrested during the periods (a) 3rd June, 1959, to 31st July, 1961, and (b) 1st August, 1961, to 30th June, 1963; and what was the total amount of fines collected from the hawkers during each period.

    Mr K. M. Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, for the period between 3rd June, 1959 and 31st July, 1961, 493 hawkers were summoned before the police courts for hawking offences and the total of the fines imposed by the courts was $4,140.

    Sir, in this period, no sort of positive action was taken to help the hawkers, and conditions became chaotic especially in congested areas and around the markets and street-corners, with the result that market stallholders left their stalls in the markets and shop-keepers left their shops to compete with the hawkers outside the markets and shops and in street-corners. In this situation of a free-for-all which did not serve the interest of the hawkers themselves, the Hawkers Department was too afraid to discharge their normal duties to the hawkers and to the people.

    Sir, for the period 1st August 1961, to 30th June, 1963, 3,214 hawkers were summoned before the police courts for hawking offences and the total of the fines imposed by the courts was $33,763.

    Sir, in the second period under reference, a new policy for the resiting of hawkers on alternative sites off the main roads and markets was adopted. The new sites they occupy are chosen in close proximity to the places from where they had been removed so as to ensure the least dislocation to their business. Every hawker who is to be removed from a clearance site is registered and is assured of a place in the new site. The places in the new sites are drawn for in a ballot held in public. The sites are properly marked out and laid out with standpipes to facilitate daily cleansing. Bins are also provided at such sites.

Column: 257



    Sir, the hawkers were also, in this second period, for the first time, given a proprietary interest in the sites they occupied which they could transfer to others for a consideration when they decided to give up their business or which could be transferred to members of their family when they die. Previously in such circumstances, their sites were declared to be vacant and were given to newcomers on the results of a ballot. Under the new system, all opportunities for graft in the allocation of pitches and hawker sites have been eliminated, as the hawker himself gets the best price for his site and his family gets the site when he dies. Under the present system also, the hawker who actually does the business on a site is licensed and if subletting is discovered, the person actually doing the business gets the licence transferred to him.

    The Housing Board has also embarked on a very enlightened policy of building hawker pitches in the Board's estates which are rented to the hawkers on small instalments to cover their cost of construction over a period of three years and which become the property of the hawker at the end of the period. Thereafter, the hawker only pays a nominal rent of $1 per month for the site which is his and which he can transfer to others for a consideration or which passes to his family when he dies.

    In addition, in furtherance of the scheme for a fair deal for hawkers, they have been allowed to ply their trade in various parts of the city and in the rural areas at nights and in selected locations once a week where their presence does not cause any traffic obstruction and where they can find a ready market for their goods.

    Sir, as a result of the enlightened policy followed in regard to hawkers in the second period, the hawker situation in the town has shown considerable improvement. The Government regrets the need for enforcing the law on hawking but this action has had to be taken in the interests of both the hawkers themselves and the public and has been reduced to the very minimum. Where new hawkers come to sites where hawkers have been resited, action has obviously to be taken against them

Column: 258

otherwise there would be no point in proceeding with resiting schemes. Also where hawkers ply their trade at street-corners or on streets which because of the heavy traffic are restricted to hawkers, action has obviously to be taken to keep the streets free for traffic.

    So with the new deal that the Government has given to the hawkers, the Government has been able to get their co-operation in keeping the city clean. The hawkers themselves understand that if the law is not enforced in a fair and reasonable manner, a free-for-all situation develops which does not in the long run serve their own interests.

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong (Jalan Kayu)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to understand why there is a great difference between the fines imposed in one period and those imposed in the other period. In the period between 3rd June, 1959, and 31st July, 1961, the fines were less than those for the period between 1st August, 1961, and 30th June, 1963. The time lapse between the two periods is not very great. Why is there also such a great difference in the number of hawkers arrested during the two respective periods? It may be an indication that after 31st July, 1961, the Government did not look after the interest of the hawkers well.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, have already answered the question. I have told the House that in the first period there was no attempt made to try to contain the hawker situation. A genuine attempt was made in the second period referred to.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in the second period, I can assure you that the Member for Bras Basah, who is closer to the hawkers than the Member for Jalan Kayu, who is the son of a rich landowner in Singapore, was a member of the Hawkers Committee, and endorsed this policy as being in the interests of the public as well as in the interests of the hawkers themselves.

INTERNATIONAL LABOUR CONFERENCE IN GENEVA
(Expenses of Mr C. V. Devan Nair)


    8. Mr Tan Cheng Tong asked the Minister for Labour whether he has any information as to who paid for the expenses of Mr C. V. Devan Nair when he attended the recent International Labour Conference in Geneva, and whom did he represent.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: The expenses of Mr C. V. Devan Nair along with other delegates who attended the recent International Labour Conference held in Geneva from 5th to 27th June, 1963, were paid by the Singapore Government.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng (Pasir Panjang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister give the names of the members of the delegation?

    The Commissioner for Labour.

Column: 260



    Mr Devan Nair,

    Two advisers to the workers' representatives - Mr Hsu Tze Kwang and Mr Ho See Beng,

    An employers' representative - Mr G. C. Thio.

    Mr Speaker: That supplementary question does not arise out of the original question. If the Minister chooses to answer, he can do so if he has the information.

    We come back to Question No. 1. Mr Low Por Tuck.

Column: 260

(Members of Singapore Team)


    1. Mr Low Por Tuck asked the Prime Minister who were the members of the Singapore team that attended the inter-governmental financial talks in Kuala Lumpur on 10th and 11th April, 1963.

If they do not ask that that be done, then the Prime Minister will send Written Answers. Can I have an indication from the Member for Havelock whether he wishes his answer tomorrow?

Column: 261

RELIGIOUS FREEDOM IN SINGAPORE AFTER MALAYSIA
(Statement by the Prime Minister)


2.47 p.m.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, whilst I was in London I was approached by the British Council of Churches about the question of religious freedom in Singapore after Malaysia. It would appear that there was some misunderstanding and not unnatural concern regarding religious liberty after Malaysia. I therefore undertook to make a declaration on religious freedom on my return to Singapore in this Assembly. It has always been the policy of the Government of Singapore to allow freedom of all religions in Singapore, and I gladly give the assurance that we will continue the policy of religious toleration.

    Members of other religions than the Muslims will appreciate that the Singapore (Constitution) Order in Council, 1958, makes it the responsibility of the Government of Singapore to protect, safeguard, support, foster, and promote the political, educational, religious, economic, social and cultural interests of the Malays. This responsibility will remain after Malaysia Day, as it will be included in the Singapore Constitution. However, the over-riding safeguard for religious freedom is contained in Article

Column: 262

11 of the Federal Constitution, which provides that every person has the right to profess and practise his religion, it is the policy of the Singapore Government to maintain the status quo in all matters of religious freedom, in other words, there will be no change after Malaysia. Article 11(4) of the Federal Constitution does give power to the State to control or restrict the propagation of any religious doctrine or belief amongst persons professing the Muslim religion. And Article 11(1) of the Constitution provides that the right to propagate the religion shall be subject to this power. The power will be exercised by the State Government and the provisions of the Federal Constitution in this matter cannot be amended without the consent of the Singapore Government.

    Sir, it is not possible for me to bind all future governments in Singapore, but I give the assurance that it is not the intention of my Government to introduce legislation to control or restrict the propagation of any religious doctrine or belief, and the present position in all matters of religious liberty will continue.

Column: 262

BREACH OF PRIVILEGE


2.51 p.m.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the Member for Queenstown is guilty of dishonourable conduct and abuse of privilege in that he did on the 14th day of June, 1963, in this House maliciously and falsely attack the integrity of the Minister for Finance by making the following statement:-

    "I remember reading in the newspaper about the Minister for Finance going along to open the `National Tower' for the firm Matsushita or something like that. I do not know; may be the Minister has some vested interests in this, and it may be that because of this that the Minister has been running along, flying all the time to Japan and Tokyo.".

Sir -

    Mr Speaker: Order. There is no debate: no speech. The motion stands referred to the Committee of Privileges under the provisions of paragraph 7 (d) (i) of Standing Order 93. The Minister for Finance will, of course, make his speech in the Committee of Privileges.

Column: 263

MALAYSIA AGREEMENT
(Motion)*


    * The amended notice of motion, standing in the name of the Prime Minister, reads as follows:-

    'In pursuance of the resolution of this House taken on the 10th June, 1963 that there should be an early settlement fair and just to both sides on the basis of the terms of the White Paper (Paper Cmd, 33 of 1961) and mindful of the long and arduous battle for merger, this House

WELCOMES the successful outcome in the final agreement reached in London on 8th July, 1963, which agreement contains the terms in the said White Paper with amendments made on a quid pro quo basis, Singapore getting a Malaysia Common Market written into the Constitution in return for a percentage of Singapore's revenue of national taxes instead of an annual lump sum as contribution for Federal services in Singapore, and

TAKING COGNIZANCE of the exchange of memoranda, on the financial arrangements as in Paper Misc. 4 of 1963 which sets out the basis on which the Singapore and Federation Governments arrived at their respective percentages and the component parts thereof, and

SUBJECT to the fulfilment of the conditions set out in the exchange of letters between the Singapore Government and the Federation Government and the Singapore Government and the British Government contained in Paper Misc 5 of 1963. this House

ADOPTS the constitutional provisions and amendments contained in Paper Cmd. 22 of 1963.'


2.53 p.m.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, I must apologise to Members of the House in not being able to present them with a final version of the Malaysia Bill even right up till now. I discussed the matter with you, Mr Speaker, Sir, on Saturday and decided that rather than wait for more further amendments to be put in which will delay the debate, we would table the Malaysia Bill as it is and introduce the amendments. I hope, in the course of the debate but certainly before adoption by this House. The position is as follows.

    Members who have read the exchange of letters will be aware that there were certain changes conceded and agreed to on the 8th July, the day when we signed or initialled the Agreement in London. In several cases, as in the case of one document which was signed by the Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya, it was not agreed to till 9.15 on the evening when we signed the Agreement. That, Sir, has provided certain drafting problems. I have been busy this morning with the State Advocate-General who is in constant communication with his counterpart in the Federation. I would have preferred to have all these amendments included in the document presented, but I think time is pressing and I have undertaken to introduce

Column: 264

the amendments before the provisions are adopted and then to produce a clean copy of the final Bill.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the Hon. the Prime Minister mentioned the date as "8th July" when the Agreement was initialled.

    The Prime Minister: Yes.

    Mr Speaker: I have been a bit puzzled about this date because the Agreement itself, which is contained in Paper Cmd. 22 of 1963, gives the date as "9th July".

    The Prime Minister: Sir, there was some difficulty about that. We foregathered at about a quarter to twelve. After 9.15 when we agreed at the Ritz, quite appropriately. Mr Speaker, Sir, the Prime Minister of the Federation took us all out to dinner to a place called the Omar Khayaam. We foregathered at Marlborough House at 11.30 and did not get down to business until 11.45. I am not quite sure at what exact time I initialled the Agreement, but I think there was some jesting with some of the participants of that Conference as to the date of it, because when the last signature was appended, the clock had moved on to Tuesday, the 9th of July. I think, for purposes of propriety, as far as I was concerned, it, was the 8th of July,. hut if the document says "9th of July", then so be it.

Column: 265



    Mr Speaker: Order. Then will the Prime Minister agree to a typographical amendment to his motion

    - instead of "8th July", it will be "9th July"?

    The Prime Minister: Yes, surely, Mr Speaker, Sir. I am not quite sure when the Agreement was made - I mean the exact time when everybody put his signature to it - but I think it might be safer if we said it was the 9th of July.

    The amendments that will be introduced - I hope some tomorrow or some this afternoon, and some the day after - are of two types. One is purely legal draftsmanship. The legal draftsman of the Federation Government, who has been seconded from the British Treasury, has suggested certain improvements in the syntax and phraseology of some of the Articles of the Constitution. There are no substantial amendments, and I think the House will not wish to quibble if the Federation wishes to take their draftsman's advice on these matters.

    But there are several other amendments of substance. We managed to have one put into the Bill. Members will note that when the general elections for 51 seats take place - it will be any time between now and three months after 31st December, depending on the will of Members of the Opposition - the position of candidates and Assemblymen will no longer be quite the same. If those who are elected on the party platform and bear the party symbol break faith with the Party, either by resigning or by being expelled, then they automatically vacate their seats in this Assembly. In other words, there will be no more musical chairs in this Chamber. The next election is an election to decide who is to govern for the next five years.

    There are two other important amendments. One, Members will notice, is contained in a letter I wrote to the Tunku, enclosing a document he signed in which it has been agreed that the power to detain gangsters even after merger and Malaysia will rest with the Singapore Government. This is a matter of some importance, Mr Speaker, Sir, particularly as we know that in certain parts of the country and certainly before 1959, gangsters played an important role

Column: 266

in elections. Well, I am afraid they will not be able to do so at the next general elections, whether it be before merger or after merger. The power, the executive authority, under the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Ordinance, rests with the Singapore Government. I think it is to the good of the peace and good order of this country. I am sorry some Members on the other side may have friends who were in Pulau Senang, but they will remain in custody. This is a matter of sufficiently grave importance for it is to be carefully spelt out in the Constitution.

    Next is the question of migration control. Under the Constitution we have afforded the Central Government authority to prevent specific persons under the Restriction of Residence Ordinance from staying in a particular part of the country. Members will remember how one Said Zahari came back to Singapore and suddenly found the ban across the causeway. He then resided in Singapore and added to the mischief that was then going on. Well, I think, in fairness, we should have a reciprocal right that we shall have no more Fong Swee Suans, or, for that matter, Lim Ching Siong, whose family is from Pontian and who will be proved ultimately to have come from Pontian; James Puthucheary, Mr Woodhull. Mr James Puthucheary was a political friend of mine, now he is only a friend. I do not see why they should add mischief to Singapore. There will be reciprocity. In other words, we will keep our bad hats in Singapore if the Federation Government so wills it, and we will have the right to request the Federation Government to keep their undesirables on the other side of the causeway. In this way, I am quite sure Singapore will become a much more peaceful and salubrious place. This power extends not only to political undesirables, but also to secret society undesirables. It may be, Mr Speaker, Sir, that just before the election, whether it is held between now or three months after the end of the year, trainloads of young men, whose political skill Consists of the bicycle chain and the knuckle duster, will come from places like Ipoh, Penang and other parts of Malaya, where they

Column: 267

do not have the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Ordinance to detain them. Members will notice that every time there is an election in a town, there is always an anguished plea for fair play by the Opposition. I leave Members to draw their own conclusions. But I say, first of all, we do not want these gentlemen to come here either before or during an election. I know of several bus owners whose business ramifications spread over the rest of Malaya and who, I am quite sure, will be able to provide quite a number of cohorts for these matters. Youth leaders, the Youth League, first they cannot come here because we will have the right to ask the Federation Government not to allow them entry; secondly, if they do slip by, they will be detained under the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Ordinance. Insofar as is humanly possible, we will try to keep Singapore the clean, sober and reasonable city that it always has been.

    For these reasons. Mr Speaker, Sir, it was not possible to give Members the Malaysia Bill until sometime, I think, yesterday morning -

    The Prime Minister resumed his seat.

    Mr Speaker: This is for the record. The paper arrived here at 9.15 a.m. We started to despatch at 10.30 a.m. and it took the whole day until 7 o'clock in the evening.

    The Prime Minister: Well, I apologise for it, Mr Speaker, Sir,I do not think it is the Government Printer's fault. He had 500 pages of electroplating to do, the Rueff Report, the Malaysia Bill, the various financial papers and the exchange of documents. I think, in all fairness, Members should read the Malaysia Bill before the debate commences. I read in the newspapers, that the Member for Anson, who was not present, said he had read the Malaysia Bill. He had bought a copy from London and had ordered hundreds of them for the Press. Well, I am sorry he has done so, because I think these copies will be a little bit out of date. They will need a lot of corrigenda. By tomorrow I hope the drafting amendments will be

Column: 268

in, and the gist, if not the final form, of at least two of these important constitutional provisions. Therefore, I propose under Standing Order 33 (2) (b) to name tomorrow 2.30 p.m. as the date for the commencement of the debate. In the meanwhile, if my Office or the State Advocate-General's Chambers can be of any use to Members on the other side who are genuinely interested in the Constitution, we shall give whatever explanation is required.

    Mr Speaker: The motion will be before the House tomorrow. Now I take it the Leader of the House will move the adjournment?

3.09 p.m.

ADJOURNMENT MOTION


    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, I move.

    That this Assembly do now adjourn.

    Question proposed.

Column: 268

INDUSTRIAL DISPUTE OF THE PORT WORKERS


    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): The Public of Singapore must have been amazed at the manner in which the Prime Minister has tried to bring peace, as he says, to the port workers. Members will recollect that as early as March this year, the public was treated to the wonderful spectacle of the Chairman of the Harbour Board instructing the police to go and nail up the premises of the Staff Association, and then a few hours later of the Prime Minister saying that he was horrified, and that he had instructed the Chairman of the Harbour Board not to do such naughty things. All this sort of play-acting really brings the P.A.P nowhere. It just makes people laugh. Here was the Chairman of the Harbour Board, a Permanent Secretary, doing the thing which he thought was what the Government wanted, and here was the Prime Minister saying that the Chairman of the Harbour Board should not do such a naughty thing. That was the start of the tussle for power between the P.A.P. and the Barisan Sosialis for the Harbour Board Staff Association: between, as they would like it to be described in more trade union terms, the N.T.U.C. and S.A.T.U.

Column: 269



    Then in May, as the matter could not be settled amicably, the Prime Minister, who had been the legal adviser to the Singapore Harbour Board Staff Association for many, many years in the past, called a meeting of the two factions in the Singapore Harbour Board Staff Association. He tried - he really did - to bring peace. He told these two factions that they should go back, talk matters over, and come to some decision whereby they could protect the interests of the workers. But, and this is what he warned them, they should not allow themselves to be made use of by pro-Communists who were just around the corner trying to cash in on the situation in an endeavour to damage Malaysia.

    Sir, it really tickled me. I have been in the Legislative Council since 1948, and the British colonial government, whenever they met with any trouble from the trade unions, always smelt a Communist behind every tree. "Ha, this is a Communist trade union. Ha, so and so is a Communist." And the Prime Minister, who was with that union for many, many years and who, as a result of the support given by that union, won resoundingly in the Tanjong Pagar election, the Tanjong Pagar by-election, and yet another Tanjong Pagar election, and was carried on the shoulders of Jamit Singh as a great victor - and now poor Jamit Singh is under detention by the same man whom he chaired -

    The Prime Minister: By your friend, the Tunku.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: - now smells a Communist behind every tree. Their boys have just found out that the Singapore Harbour Board Staff Association, because the P.A.P. have found difficulty in controlling them to their way of thinking, are now getting into the hands of the Communists.

    The two factions, as I have said, went back and I do not know what they did; whether they did try to resolve their differences; but it would seem that they could not resolve their differences. In May the Prime Minister found it difficult to drum some sense into the group of trade unionists who would not follow

Column: 270

the P.A.P. party line. He gave them a sort of ultimatum, "Unless you boys behave, you watch out!" Although he did not use the same memorable phrase - "I can fix you, but you cannot fix me!" - it meant the same thing. "You boys watch out!" He told these two groups and I do not know whether they did try to resolve their differences. But it would seem that things have gone from bad to worse. The Prime Minister thought that something must be done to teach these boys, who would not listen to the great words of wisdom of the Prime Minister, a much-needed lesson.

    The trouble between the two groups was not resolved. But then the one group that did not owe allegiance to the P.A.P. decided that they should give an ultimatum to the Harbour Board to have their demands finalised within a certain period.

    That really got the Prime Minister wild.
